newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Oct 9.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Oct 9.

text.p: American Brands Inc intends to spin off its British Gallaher cigarette business and change its name to Fortune Brands, the Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday.
* McDonald's Corp named Jack Greenberg to oversee its more than 10,000 restaurants in the United States and try to revive their business.

* General Motors Corp said it did not have the money to create new jobs in Canada to replace ones that might disappear by shifting parts work outside the company, a guarantee that union leaders are demanding of GM.
* Federal Express Corp is to announce on Wednesday a software package that will enable company clients to buy and sell products on the Internet and let it deliver the goods afterwards.
* AT&T Corp introduced a service designed to help businesses design, manage and advertize electronic storefronts.
* Price Waterhouse is considering acquisitions or joint ventures in a plan to double or triple revenues in the next four years.
* NASD alleged that brokerage firm Sterling Foster & Co made illicit profits from improper underwriting.
* U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission launched a probe into complaints by a former NASD examiner that the group obstructed her investigation into municipal-bond markets.
* The chip industry's leading indicator rose in September, showing signs of recovery in the semiconductor market.
* Viacom Inc's Blockbuster is planning to shutter up to 10 percent of its music shops.
* Reuters Holdings Plc suspended a plan to buy back $958 million of its shares.
* Koll Real Estate Group and Leon Black's Apollo Real Estate plan a bid for race-track owner Santa Anita.

* Intel Corp is not discussing its prospects with investors for fear of the potential effect of Proposition 211, which would make it easier for shareholders to sue companies for making misleading statements.
* The Dow Jones industrials fell to 5966.77. The NASDAQ Composite Index also ended lower as the U.S. dollar closed mixed.

* The U.S. bond market ended lower as $10 billion in new supply in the form of 10-year Treasury notes entered the market and investors kept consolidating some of the last week's big gains in bond prices.
